Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION: The facility failed to respond to a resident's asthma attack at school
in a timely manner.
INVESTIGATION:
Allegation was made the facility does not respond timely to resident’s medical needs
and Youth B and Youth C had asthma attacks at school without their nebulizers.
2

A conference call was made on 12/18/2019 that included Foster Care Worker 1, Foster
Care Worker 2, and Foster Care Worker 3. The call included a discussion of the
allegations related to the medical care of Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C and if the
facility has a policy related to the access to a nebulizer when the residents are at
school.
Supervisor 1 submitted documentation on 12/11/2019 related to the medical care
provided for Youth A and Youth B. Supervisor 1 was interviewed at the facility on
01/13/2020. Supervisor 1 confirmed the medical treatment provided for Youth B.
Supervisor 1 reported Youth B has often refused the antibiotic medications prescribed
for Youth B to help Youth B with her medical issues. Supervisor 1 reported a 30 day
notice of discharge is being issued for Youth B in part due to Youth B’s lack of
cooperation with her medical care. Supervisor 1 submitted a policy statement on
01/14/2020 related to nebulizers and other medications for residents while at school.
The policy was developed after the incident under investigation. The policy stated,
“Youth who utilize inhalers for emergency situations will have access to these items
during the school day. The staff will be responsible for maintaining and assisting with
administration of medical needs.”
Youth A (DOB: 02/03/04) was interviewed at the facility on 02/10/2020. Youth A had
previously reported going to the doctor on 12/06/2019 and allegedly not having a follow
up appointment as recommended. Documentation was received that a follow up
appointment was completed 12/10/2019. During the interview on 02/10/2020 Youth A
confirmed the completion of the additional medical appointments as recommended.
Youth B (DOB: 06/16/03) was interviewed at the facility on 01/13/2020. Youth B
reported having an asthma attack at school and that required a nebulizer. Youth B was
receiving a breathing treatment at the facility when Youth B started coughing up blood.
Youth B was then taken to Central Michigan Community Hospital for treatment. Youth
B was also given a breathing treatment at the hospital and a chest x-ray was also
completed.
Youth C (DOB: 05/01/02) was interviewed at the facility on 02/10/2020. Youth C stated
she had an asthma attack when she was at school and the staff did not have access to
her nebulizer at the time. Youth C stated facility staff are normally at the school and
they have a nebulizer with them to be used as needed. Youth C stated that for some
reason the staff member with the nebulizer forgot to leave the nebulizer at the facility
when they went off duty. Youth C stated there was no backup nebulizer at the time of
this incident. Youth C stated she did not have access to a nebulizer until they were able
to contact the staff member who had the nebulizer. Youth C stated that since the time
of this incident the facility maintains a backup nebulizer, so a similar incident does not
happen in the future. Youth C stated she was able to recover at the time of this incident
without the use of the nebulizer.
3

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
ANALYSIS: The findings of this investigation indicate the facility does
maintain appropriate medical care for the residents, but Youth C
did not have access to a nebulizer while she was at school at
the time of a specific incident that was a part of this
investigation.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
TA: It is recommended that the facility expand upon the
policy/practice statement that was submitted to include more
details to ensure an oversite is not repeated like the one that
occurred and delayed the access of Youth C to her medication.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend with the submission and acceptance of an approved corrective action
plan the current license status of this child care institution-private be maintained.
